RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

 
A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis1 

The rural sector underpins the economic and social structure of the economy of Pakistan. The 
2. 
agriculture sector contributes about 25% of gross domestic product, is the source of 74% of exports,2 
and  provides  direct  employment  for  about  44%  of  the  workforce.  Despite  the  introduction  of 
macroeconomic  structural  reforms  in  the  latter  half  of  the  1990s,  there  are  major  concerns  about 
agricultural productivity and growth, with sector growth of about 3.7% only just exceeding population 
growth of 2.5% annually over the past decade. The rural, nonfarm sector is a major contributor to the 
economy, but performance in this sector has been equally restrained. This has adversely affected the 
livelihoods and growth prospects for all 68% of households living in the rural areas of the country. 
Major challenges remain if real economic and social progress is to be attained, including (i) reducing 
poverty,  (ii) improving  governance,  (iii) extending  fiscal  reforms,  (iv) improving  the  balance  of 
payments  situation,  (v)  restoring  investor  confidence,  (vi) accelerating  economic  growth,  and 
(vii) improving social indicators.  
 
3. 
Poverty  in  Pakistan  has  a  significant  rural  dim ension, and addressing the poverty situation 
represents a major policy focus into the next decade. Levels of poverty fell during the 1980s, while the 
number of poor more than doubled during the 1990s. The number of poor was estimated in June 
1999 as 45 million or one third of the population, in 6.3 million households.3 Of these, 33 million or 
73% (4.7 million households) are estimated to live in rural areas. These figures, significant as they 
are, mask the actual extent of poverty in rural Pakistan as “poverty” is now recognized as not merely 
an  income-related  phenomenon.  Poverty  is  also  reflected  in  deprivation  of  key  quality  of  life 
opportunities,  with  feelings  of  vulnerability  and  powerlessness  the  most  important  intangibles  that 
shape the lives of the poor. The denial of people’s basic rights by public officials, nonimplementation 
of protective measures and legislation, substandard service delivery, and a lack of access to fair and 
affordable  grievance-settlement  mechanisms,  including  courts,  all  further  exacerbate  feelings  of 
vulnerability.  
 
4. 
Poverty levels are high in Sindh: 37% of the population live below the poverty line; 20% of the 
urban  and  53%  of  the  rural  population  are  poor.4 While economic growth in the farm and nonfarm 
sectors is a necessary condition for improving rural livelihoods, this growth must have a core pro-poor 
dimension  if  it  is  to  generate  significant  improvements  in  the  livelihoods  of  the  agricultural 
communities in rural Sindh (Appendix 1). Here, structural rigidities, imbalance in access to resources, 
the  differential  impacts  of  the  introduction  of  new  technologies,  weak  governance,  and  a  lack  of 
empowerment constrain any benefits of sector economic growth from “trickling down” to the majority 
of the population, which consists of the over half of households that do not own agricultural land, and 
the further one quarter of households that own 2 hectares (ha) or less.

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

5. 
The  four  districts  (of  Badin,  Mirpurkhas,  Sanghar,  and  Thatta)  have  a  combined  rural 
population of about 4.6 million in 0.8 million households, or 27% of the rural population of Sindh 
province.  Poverty  is  widespread  throughout  the  four  districts.  According  to  nationwide 
comparative  rankings  of  social  indicators,  none  of  the  four  districts  was  found  in  the  first  or 
second quartile, two were in the third, and two were in the bottom quartile. Badin appeared as the 
poorest  district  in  Sindh.  Health  and  education  indicators  are  very  poor.  Adult  literacy  rates  are 
10.5%  for  women  and  34.7%  for  men.  Rural  link  roads  are  in  urgent  need  of  upgrading.  Only 
10.5% of the rural population has access to safe drinking water and sanitation. Drinking water is 
the  major  expressed  need  of  the  rural  poor.  Women  participate  in  agricultural  work,  are  fully 
responsible for the livestock, and manage the household and children, but are largely bypassed 
by extension services. Levels of household indebtedness are high.5 Technologies, transportation, 
and  market  linkages  are  also  very  poor.  This  situation  is  compounded  through  insufficient 
supplies of irrigation water to meet demand, droughts, and other natural calamities.  
 
6. 
A  majority  of  rural  households  in  the  four  districts  do  not  own  agricultural  or  homestead 
land. Tenant farms alone represent 44% of all private farms. Of those who do own land in rural 
areas, fewer than 20% are large landlords6 but this group owns over 60% of the private farms.7 
The existing sharecropping tenancy system, concentrated in the canal-irrigated areas of the four 
districts, is historically deep-rooted and perpetuates the deeply entrenched poverty of tenants and 
agricultural labor through unbalanced revenue-sharing and cost-sharing arrangements (Appendix 
2,  paras.  11–13,  Table  A2.2)  and  a  complex  system  of  dependencies.  Changes  over  time,  the 
influx of migrants, and the introduction of modern technologies have altered the relationship to the 
disadvantage  of  the  hari.8  The  landlord  meets  the  haris’  needs  (e.g.,  for  agricultural  inputs, 
consumption,  social  events,  emergencies)  through  advances,  with  the  accounts  of  these 
transactions  kept  by  him,  and  often  not  transparent.  However,  even  if  these  accounts  were 
managed openly, haris’ extremely low literacy rate would inhibit their control over the entries. The 
debt accumulates over the years. Haris cannot leave the landlord without clearing their debt, and 
become bonded.9 The bonded labor issue is politically sensitive and discussing it has frequently 
been  interpreted  as  threatening  the  existing  power  structure.  Innumerable  dialogues  between 
various actors10 indicate some inclination to begin changing the system.  
 
The existing legal framework provides the basis for such changes and most of the relevant

Governance  has  emerged  as  one  of  Pakistan’s  foremost  development  concerns.  On  14 
8. 
August 2001, a new integrated three-tier local government system was installed. The Government is 
relying on its devolution program to promote competition, ownership, and accountability in the delivery 
of  public  services,  and  on  the  active  involvement  of  people  in  community  issues.  This  is  a  major 
opportunity  for  more  people-centered,  rights -  and  responsibility-based  government  structures,  but 
risks relate to weak technical and institutional capacity to handle the diverse set of functions involved, 
the  reluctance  of  provincial  governments  to  devolve  administrative  and  financial  powers,  and  the 
likelihood  of  control  by  local  elites.  The  large  group  of  the  rural  poor,  particularly  women,  is  only 
minimally represented in civil society organizations, and the rural poor lack the power to exercise their 
basic  rights  or  to  access  public  services.  Community-based  organizations  (CBOs)  will  have  to 
increase their efforts to enhance social processes. Nongovernment organizations (NGOs) are required 
in supporting the interests and developing the capacities of CBOs. A comprehensive study of NGO 
and CBO capacities13 shows that NGOs in Sindh have demonstrated their capacity to work in difficult 
circumstances  and  remote  areas. However, their area coverage is limited, while cooperation with 
each other and with government, as well as their managerial capacities, need to be further developed.  
 
9. 
The design of the Project in southern Sindh therefore takes into consideration (i) the complex 
social, cultural, legal, and political environment, in particular the feudal relationship between landlords, 
haris, and landless laborers; (ii) the importance of confidence building and awareness raising of legal 
rights and obligations among beneficiaries, landlords, and local government, and of compliance with 
existing  legislation;  (iii) the  need  to  address  key  constraints  limiting  livelihood  enhancement 
opportunities of the target population (e.g., levels of literacy, access to appropriate technology, and 
community  infrastructure  needs);  (iv) the  overall  capacity  of  the  Sindh  government  and  the  new 
district governments, NGOs, and other agencies, and the need for clear definition of their roles and 
coordination between concerned agenc ies; and (v) appropriate arrangements for the management of 
the Project, taking into account the devolution process.  
 
Important aspects therefore incorporated in the design of the proposed Project include (i) the

2. 

Enhanced Social Processes at the Community Level 

 
The population in rural Sindh is extremely scattered24 and lives in very small settlements. 
22. 
In the four districts, only 35.2% of the rural population live in villages of 50 households and above 
(Appendix 5, Table A5.1). To improve outreach to the poor target population and assure effective 
use  of  investments,  a  thorough  process  of  selecting  villages  for  project  interventions  will  be 
applied  (Appendix  5).  One  “lead”  NGO  per  district  will  be  selected  to  support the CBOs in their 
community  interventions.  A  more  intensive  level  of  intervention  will  be  applied  for  a  subset  of 
villages  through  a  holistic  approach  to  improved  settlement  (village  planning,  small-scale 
infrastructure, and village link roads).  
 
23. 
The process of selecting the groups of villages that will participate in the various levels of

process  and  the  results.  A  second  series  of  workshops  will  introduce  the  Project  to  CBOs 
operating in the area. Awareness-raising campaigns and delivery of services to village groups will 
be  accompanied  by  an  intensive  process  of  practice-oriented  capacity  building  for  CBOs  to 
enable them to function more effectively, and to extend their outreach. It is expected that some 
640 CBOs will be directly strengthened, and that these will provide support and capacity-building 
services to around 3,200 village groups (at least one third of them women’s groups).  
 
A  comprehensive  package  for  functional  and  numeric  literacy  will  be  developed,

government’s new executive district office for literacy and the office for community development. 
Head trainers will provide training to trainers from the CBOs and the district government. CBOs 
and  the  district  government  will  provide  training  of  functional  and  numeric  literacy  for  village 
groups. It is anticipated that head training programs will be organized around four workshops and

literacy training to an estimated 3,200 village groups. 
 

3. 

Improved Rural Livelihoods 

 
In  the  project  area,  wheat  is  the  predominant  crop,  followed  by  cotton,  rice,  and 
25.

fruits.  Marginal  farmers  tend  to  concentrate  on  wheat,  cotton,  rice,  and  fodder  crops.  Haris

strategy. Improvements in rural livelihoods will be carried out through four main groups of needs-
based community activities (i) strengthening agricultural support services, (ii) improving livestock 
management,  (iii) introducing  appropriate  farm  and  household  technologies,  and  (iv) improving 
access to institutional credit.

Special Features 

34. 
The Project has a number of unique and important features of design and arrangements 
in  implementation  including  (i) clear  targeting  of  project  components  to  specific  beneficiary 
groups; (ii) focus on women according to a clearly defined gender strategy and plan (Appendix 7); 
(iii) demand-driven  identification  and  prioritization  combined  with  a  spatial  planning  approach  to 
project  interventions;  (iv) district  level  implementation  arrangements;  and  (v) a  partnership 
between government, NGOs, CBOs, and beneficiaries in project activities.

The Project will apply a comprehensive set of selection criteria for its interventions to assure 
outreach  to  the  target  groups.  To  meet  spatial  concerns,  more  intensive  interventions  such  as 
settlement infrastructure improvement, will only take place in villages meeting an additional set of 
secondary criteria. These villages are considered as future “growth poles”, where services should be 
more concentrated to attract people from the small and scattered villages (Appendix 5).

Project  activities  are  programmed,  coordinated,  and  implemented  at  the  district  level  in 
support of the Government’s devolution process, with project coordination being a provincial task.

implementing  subcomponents,  and  monitoring  project  activities  will  be  at  the  district  level  and

and the district government, while thematic NGOs, provincial agencies, and specialized institutes 
will  provide  capacity  building  and  backstopping  as  required.  The  focus  is  therefore  on  capacity 
building  at  the  district  level  of  both  NGOs  and  district  government,  with  strong  linkages  to  the 
CBOs, which are the focal point for both identifying needs and priorities, and for service delivery.

60. 
Rural Society, Internal Village Organization, and Gender. Rural society in the project 
area  is  heterogeneous  and  highly  complex.  It  is  governed  by  traditional  principles  of  castes, 
tribes, religion, gender, political affiliations, and origin, which define the relationship between the 
poor and the ruling class. Stratification below the poverty line is low with the majority of the village 
population  being  poor  and  very  poor.  The  goths  (villages)  and  their  internal  organization  reflect 
the  heterogeneity  of  the  population.  With  in-depth  knowledge  of  the  delicately  balanced 
relationships,  the  distribution  of  power, behavioral restrictions, norms and traditions, the Project 
can organize villages around common interests. To achieve this, the Project will use a strategy of 
working  with  selected  lead  NGOs  and  their  CBO  partners.  Gender  disparities  are  marked  and 
female members of the target groups are more disadvantaged than the males. The movement of 
women living in the villages is restricted; rules of gender segregation and purdah apply depending 
on  tribe  or  caste  affiliation.  Women  from  outside,  however,  can  move  freely.  The  Project  has 
prepared  a  detailed  gender  strategy  and  plan  (Appendix  7),  which  emphasizes  improving 
women’s  access  to  services,  and  supports  the  introduction  of  labor-saving  appropriate 
technologies  and  the  improvement  of  women’s  livestock  management skills. It provides for one 
full-time  gender  specialist  per  district,  engaging  thematic  NGOs  on  gender  issues,  and  bridging 
the present gap in women’s access to services.

SECTOR/SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 

 
1. 
The rural sector underpins the economic and social structure of the economy of Pakistan. 
The  agriculture  sector  contributes  about  25%  of  gross  domestic  product,  is  the  source  of  74%  of 
exports,1 and provides direct employment  for about 44% of the workforce. Despite the introduction 
of macroeconomic structural reforms in the latter half of the 1990s, there are major concerns about 
agricultural  productivity  and  growth,  with  sector  growth  of  about  3.7%  only  just  exceeding 
population growth of 2.5% annually over the past decade. The rural, nonfarm sector is also a major 
contributor  to  the  economy,  but  performance  in  this  sector  has  been  equally  restrained.  This  has 
adversely affected the livelihoods and growth prospects for all the  68% of households that live in 
the rural areas of the country.  
 
2. 
While  economic  growth  in  the  farm  and  nonfarm  sectors  is  a  necessary  condition  for 
improving  rural  livelihoods,  it  is  not  a  sufficient  condition2  and  nowhere  is  this  more  clearly 
demonstrated  than  in  the  rural  areas  of  southern  Sindh.  Here,  structural  rigidities,  imbalance  in 
access to resources, the impacts of the introduction of some new technologies,3 weak governance, 
and a lack of empowerment constrain the benefits of sector economic growth from “trickling down” 
to  the  over  half  of  households  that  do  not  own  agricultural  land,  and  the  further  one  quarter  of 
households  that  own  2  hectares  (ha)  or  less  (termed  “marginal”  farmers).  These  two  groups  are 
represented  in  all  facets  of  the  poverty  spectrum,  not  only  in  terms  of  income  poverty  but  also 
exhibiting  deprivation  in  key  quality  of  life  opportunities  (e.g.,  access  to  education,  health  care, 
nutrition, and safe water and sanitation), as well as vulnerability and powerlessness. This situation 
is exemplified in the results of poverty surveys where districts in southern Sindh are some of the 
least developed in the province and in the country; primary enrollment rates are the lowest in the 
country  for  the  lowest  income  quintile;  70–80%  of  rural households in selected districts are poor 
and malnourished; infant mortality rates are among the highest in the country; and access to public 
services is extremely restricted4 (using issuance of national identity cards as a proxy). 
 
3. 
The  factors  that  constrain  the  ability  of  households  in  rural  Sindh  to  make  significant 
improvements in their livelihoods are diverse and interdependent. They are both the limitations to 
directly improving household income and the compounding effects of a host of other factors. These 
include  the  deeply  skewed  distribution  of  power  and  resources;  an  institutional  and  political 
framework  that  exhibits  weak  governance  in  terms  of  poor  fiscal  management;  a  lack  of 
transparency; inefficient and inadequate delivery of core public services; and a lack of egalitarian 
participation in, and access to, the political process.

Agricultural Benefits 

7. 
To  indicate  the  financial  impacts  of  project  interventions  on  the  target  group,  financial 
farm  models  have  been  prepared  for  average  hari  farms  in  the  project  area.  Based  on  PPTA 
and  SSTA  findings,  an  average  farm  size  of  1.92  hectares  (ha)  has  been  adopted.  While  the 
average size of a hari farm in the four districts is quite similar, cropping patterns and hence the 
analysis reflect separate farm models for each of the four districts. Given that the target group 
farmers are mainly haris who do not make land use decisions, it is anticipated that the impacts 
of the Project on cropping patterns will be minimal. For the purpose of this analysis, it has been 
assumed  that  the  only  change  in  the  cropping  pattern  will  be  a  marginal  increase  in  the  area 
under vegetables, which will be due to the promotion of homestead vegetable gardening among 
women.  At  full  development,  the  cropping  intensity  is  anticipated  to  grow  by  less  than  0.25% 
(from 131.0 to 131.3). 
 
8. 
While, in theory, there is a significant room for improvement in crops yields, conservative 
yield  increases  have  been  assumed  for  the  purposes  of  this  analysis,  reflecting  the  large 
number of factors that impact on agricultural productivity. It has been assumed that in the cases 
of  wheat  and  rice  paddy,  more  focused  activities  such  as  village-level  improved  seed 
multiplication and resource conservation/zero tillage cultivation3 will generate yield increases of 
10%. The yields of all other crops have been assumed to increase by 5%, except for sugarcane 
where  only  a  2%  yield  increase  is  anticipated  as  district  yields  are  already  higher  than  the 
provincial  average.  In  case  of  livestock  productivities,  it  has  been  assumed  that  village-level 
training  in  improved  livestock  management,  training  of  village-based  livestock  workers,  and 
improved milk and dairy product marketing, will increase milk and meat production by 10%. 
 
9. 
Any improvements in productivity or changes in cropping pattern and cropping intensities 
have  been  assumed  to  take  place  over  a  period  of  5  years.  Productivity  improvements  have 
been summarized in Table A2.1, with detailed crop and livestock models, cropping patterns and 
farm budgets being presented in Supplementary Appendix E.

Financial Impact on Haris and Landowners 

11. 
The  amended  STA  improves  both  the  system  of  sharing  input  costs  between  the  haris 
and  the  landowners—reducing  the  burden  on  the  hari  (Table  A2.2)—and  provides  better 
security  of  tenure  through  streamlining  registration.  Interventions  through  the  improved  rural 
livelihoods  component  lead  to  improved  productivity.  Reduced  input  costs  for  the  hari  and 
increased  productivity  are  expected  to  result  in  significant  financial  benefits  for  haris, which 
directly  impact  on  their  poverty  status.  In  addition,  amended  STA  provisions  relating  to  debt 
allow  a  hari  to  seek  better  terms  with  other  landowners  to  pay  back  the  loan  instead  of 
continuing under adverse terms with the landowner to which he is indebted. In conjunction with 
improved security of tenure, the ability to seek better terms from other landowners encourages 
more investment and effort by the hari, which consequently results in higher productivity.

A. 

Introduction 

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 

1. 
To a large extent, many of the expected economic benefits of the Sindh Rural Development 
Project  cannot  be  readily  quantified,  particularly  those  from  the  improved  governance  and  legal 
support  component,  the  enhanced  social  processes  at  the  community  level  component,  and  the 
upgraded  rural  infrastructure  and  settlement  improvement  component.  For  example,  the  improved 
governance and legal support component aims to improve recognition of and compliance with, legal 
rights, and build the institutional capacities of stakeholders. Similarly, the enhanced social processes 
at  the  community  level  component  aims  to  organize  the  communities  to  benefit  from  activities  to 
improve their livelihoods and to ensure implementation of activities in the improved governance and 
legal  support  component.  Activities  under  the  upgraded  rural  infrastructure  and  settlement 
improvement  component  aim  to  improve  living  conditions  by  upgrading  drinking  water  supply, 
sanitation,  drainage,  street  pavement  and  access,  and  will  result  in  benefits  that  are  largely 
unquantifiable.  
 
Activities under the improved rural livelihoods component and the improved district link roads 
2. 
subcomponent have more quantifiable benefits. As the development of village groups is the key to 
delivery  of  the  services  in  all  components,  and  project  management  support  facilitates  efficient 
implementation,  costs  pertaining  to  these  components  have  been  appropriately  apportioned 
between all components. 
 
B. 

Methodology 

The  Project  has  an  implementation  period  of  7  years  and  the  economic  life  of  the 
3. 
interventions  has  been  assumed  to  be  20  years.  The  prevailing  interbank  exchange  rate 
(PRs60.12/$1)  has  been  used  and  a  discount  rate  of  12%  adopted  for  net  present  value  (NPV) 
assessments.  A  world  price  numeraire  has  been  used.  World  Bank  commodity  price  projections 
have  been  used  to  estimate  economic  prices  for  traded  crop  outputs  and  inputs.  Prices  for  wheat, 
rice  paddy,  and  seed  cotton  are  based  on  export  parity,  while  import parity is used for sugarcane, 
milk,  urea  and  di-ammonium phosphate  (Supplementary  Appendix  E).  To  reflect  local  under- and 
unemployment in the labor market, a shadow wage rate of 0.75 of the market wage is incorporated, 
while other inputs have been adjusted by a standard conversion factor of 0.90. For the purpose of 
this analysis, the crop and livestock models adopted are described in Appendix 2.  
 

1. 

District Link Roads Models 

 
4. 
The methodology employed to evaluate the district roads subcomponent closely follows that 
adopted for the recently approved Road Sector Development Program.1 The main impact has been 
assumed  to  be  savings  in  the  vehicle  operating  costs  (Table  A11.1).  Passenger  traffic  levels  are 
based  on  the  survey  data  from  the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  and  small-scale 
technical  assistance  and  data  used  by  the  Road  Sector  Development  Program.  Goods  traffic 
volumes  have  been  quantified  by  estimating  village  level  production  and  consumption  levels  and 
assessing the volumes of surpluses and deficits to be transported. Benefits have been quantified by 
comparing the weighted average costs of transportation with and without the district link roads. 

                                                 
1   ADB. 2001. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan to the Islamic 
Republic  of  Pakistan  for  the  Road  Sector  Development  Program.  Manila.  This  sector  loan  includes  the  Sindh  Rural 
Development  Project’s  districts  and  presents  a  sample  assessment  for  one  of  the  roads  in  Sanghar  district.  The

Nonquantifiable Benefits 

 
8. 
The  Project  will  generate  a  wide  range  of  nonquantifiable  benefits  under  the  improved 
governance  and  legal  support  component.  Implementation  of  the  Amended  Sindh  Tenancy  Act, 
1950  will  improve  lives  of  tenants  through  more  favorable  sharing  arrangements.  Some  575  field 
staff  and  40  taluka  and  district  officers  of  the  Revenue  Administration  will  be  trained.  Proper 
maintenance  of  records  will  enable  tenants  to  benefit  from  protection  against  eviction  under  the 
legislation  and  exercising  their  fundamental  rights.  This  component  includes  a  rights awareness 
campaign  through  mass  media,  which  will  benefit  beyond  the  four  districts.  Accompanied  by  legal 
advice from 24 paralegals trained by the Project, this will enable target groups to access the legal 
system. 
 
9. 
The main purpose of the village groups developed under the enhanced social processes at 
the community level component is to act as delivery mechanism for all project services. The 3,200 
village  groups  covering  some  96,000  households  will  be  provided  with  functional  and  numeric 
literacy training. Improved literacy will enable them to keep records of their transactions, and provide 
access  to  information  on  rights,  hygiene  and  basic  health,  nutrition,  and  basic  livelihood  skills,  as 
well as on accessing credit. 
 
The improved rural livelihoods component will reduce workloads and improve the quality of 
10. 
life  through  introducing  appropriate  household  technologies  in  some  1,600  villages  and  through 
reducing water logging and salinity in a similar number of villages. It will also support and facilitate 
the  expansion  of  income  generation  activities  that  will  have  spillover  benefits  to  the  nontarget 
groups. 
 
11. 
The  upgraded  rural  infrastructure  and  settlement  improvement  component  will  impact 
positively  on  450  smaller  villages  (50–100  households)  and  300  larger  villages  (100–200 
households)  involving  an  estimated  78,500  households.  The  activities  mix  in  each  settlement  will 
vary  according  to  needs.  It  is  anticipated  that  these  will  include  drinking  water  supply,  sanitation, 
drainage, street pavements, and village link roads. In addition, district link roads will result in savings 
in travel time, improved access to social services such as health and education, reduced consumer 
prices, improved market access, and reduced spoilage.

SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY 

Poverty in Pakistan 

After  falling  in  the  1980s,  poverty  rose  in  Pakistan  during  the  1990s.  At  the  end  of  the 
1. 
1980s,  one  of  five  Pakistanis  were  poor;  today  it  is  one  in  three.1 The Planning Commission 
announced  Pakistan’s  official  poverty  line  in  July  2002.2  Estimates  agree  on  the  incidence  of 
poverty  currently  ranging  at  30–35%  with  poverty  being  higher  in  rural  than  urban  areas. 
Pockets of severe poverty exist in southern Punjab, almost all of Balochistan, and large parts of 
Sindh.  Poverty  is  also  manifested  along  gender  lines.  Women’s  access  and  control  over 
productive  resources  are  extremely  limited.  Women’s  mobility  is  restricted,  and  gender 
segregation and female seclusion are practiced. The female labor force participation rate is very 
low, but women play a significant role in the agriculture sector.  
 
B. 

Rural Livelihoods and Poverty in the Project Area 

1. 

Social Organization and Village Pattern 

2. 
Heterogeneity  and  Complexity  of  Rural  Society.  Rural  society  in  the  project  area  is 
heterogeneous and highly complex. The distribution of power is along the lines of caste, tribe, 
religion,  gender,  political  affiliation,  and  origin.  It  follows  traditional  rules,  which  define  the 
relationship between the poor and the ruling class. Stratification along poverty lines is low with 
the  majority  of  the  village  population  poor  or  very  poor  and  consisting  of  haris,  agricultural 
laborers, and marginal owners-cum-tenants.3 Besides sedentary groups, an unknown number of 
semi-nomadic  groups  from  the  Thar  Desert  follow  well-established  migration  patterns  and 
respond  to  contemporary  labor  demands  in  the  agricultural  areas  of  the four project districts. 
They settle temporarily at the fringes of villages, on public or private land, where water, grazing 
grounds, or work opportunities allow them to survive for limited periods of time.  
 
Village Pattern and Internal Organization. Single villages (goths) can be more or less 
3. 
homogeneous  in  their  composition  with  people  belonging  to  one  or  more  castes  or  kinship 
groups.  The  villages  are  clearly  demarcated  by  fences,  thorny  bushes,  or  walls  into  areas, 
called  para. Paras are internally  homogeneous and often share common ancestors. They are 
further subdivided into extended families, which can comprise several households. Households 
are  defined  as  groups  of  people  sharing  one  common  kitchen.  The  goth  is  an  exclusive 
geographic  area  of  its  residents.  Its  informal  rules  govern  the  patterns  of  affiliation  and 
leadership. Depending on the caste or tribal affiliation, women from different paras may (or may 
not) be able to visit each other. The rules of purdah and gender segregation apply to different 
degrees. Women from outside can move freely inside the goth, while male visitors to a village 
have only restricted access.  Despite  this  heterogeneity,  villages  can  be  organized  by  a  body 
from  outside  the  village  around  common  interests,  using  local  knowledge  of  the  delicately 
balanced relationships, the distribution of power, behavioral restrictions, norms, and traditions. 
Organizations able to assist in this process need to be from the area and understand its power 
structures.

3. 

Sharecropping Tenancy in Sindh 

5. 
Tenancy System. The tenancy system in southern Sindh is concentrated in the canal-
irrigated areas of the four districts. It is deep-rooted and its feudal features reflect an extremely 
skewed  distribution  of  power.  Although  slowly  decreasing  in  importance,  tenancy  under 
sharecropping arrangements continues as a major type of land tenure. The tenant is the  hari—
literally, “wielder of the plough”.4 Under a simple sharing system, the landlord provided the land 
to a hari and his family, and paid land revenue and water charges. The hari provided the labor, 
a pair of bullocks, and covered all other costs. The output was shared equally. Contracts were 
and still are oral, with the minimum contract period being 1 year.  
 
6. 
The  relationship  between  the  landlord  and  the  hari  is  far  more  than  an  economic 
arrangement.  It  is  a  complex  system,  with  advantages  and  disadvantages  for  both  sides,  but 
from a contemporary perspective it is a highly imbalanced relationship. The control over major 
resources  (land  and  water)  is  in  the  hands  of  the  landlord,  who  also  decides  on  the  crops  to 
cultivate and on the use of the family labor. The landlord may ask the hari or his family members 
for labor without payment (begar). On the other side, the hari-landlord relationship is also one of 
respect, with the landlord appreciating agricultural knowledge and skills and the commitment of 
the  hari  to  his  work.  For  the  hari,  the  landlord  provides  continuity  and  stability  in  the  labor 
arrangement, and credit in cash or in kind when needed. Trust and confidence have therefore 
also  been  characteristics  of  the  relationship  (Table  A12.2).  The  system  also  provides  ample 
opportunities  for  abuse,  with  ethnic,  political,  religious,  and  gender  dimensions  increasing  this 
likelihood.  Non-Muslim  haris,  mostly  from  the  Hindu  scheduled  castes,  are  considered 
economically  more  disadvantaged  and  oppressed. Muslim haris with particular clan and caste 
ties have stronger links and better bargaining positions with respect to landlords.

Debt and Credit Dimension.  Haris  get  into  debt  through  advances  they  receive  from 
the  landlord  in  cash  or  kind  (peshgi)  to  meet  costs  of  cultivation  or  simply  to  cover  regular 
household consumption requirements. The expectation is that the account is settled at the time 
of the harvest, but in reality the debt accumulates from one year to the next, as the share of the 
yield is not enough to survive, let alone to pay off the loans.5 If a hari wants to move, the new 
landlord  takes  over  the  accumulated  debt.  The  landlord  keeps  the  account,  transactions  are 
rarely  transparent,  and  the  landlord  may  be  overvaluing  inputs  and  undervaluing  outputs.  But 
even  if  accounts  were  managed  more  openly,  haris’  extremely  low  literacy  rate  would  inhibit 
their  control  over  the  entries.  According  to  the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  report, 
the sizes of their loans ranged between PRs20,000 and more than PRs100,000. Indebtedness 
is  widespread.  In  fact  in  Badin,  74%  of  the  hari  households  were  indebted  to  the  landlord,  in 
Mirpurkhas the indebtedness was 100%. In Sanghar, indebtedness was reported by the small-
scale  technical  assistance  report  at  between  PRs5,000  and  more  than  PRs30,000.  This  is 
confirmed through another study6 in Sanghar, according to which virtually all haris in one of the 
study villages were indebted to the landlord. Haris are not allowed to leave the landlord unless 
they  clear  their  accumulated  debt,  which  is  possible  only  with  a  cash  advance  from  another 
landlord.7 This relationship of debt bondage is a politically sensitive issue. Landlords in Sindh, 
government representatives, and other power holders continue to deny the existence of bonded 
labor, using a variety of strategies. Some argue that the phenomenon is culturally deep-rooted 
and cannot be understood by outsiders. Others agree to a limited number of abuses. However, 
the application of specific legislation against bonded labor—namely the Bonded Labour System 
(Abolition) Act, 1992—to agricultural labor has been questioned and is currently under review in 
the Supreme Court of Pakistan.

aquatics, shrubs, and a few trees surrounding wetland sites. Of the farm area, 17.6% consists of 
waterlogged or salinized lands; forested land makes up a tiny 0.25% of the area. 
 
The ecology of Mirpurkhas and the western parts of Sanghar district is governed by the 
7. 
canal  irrigation  network  and  the  LBOD  system,  which  drains  saline  effluent  from  some  of  its 
areas. The former has been adversely impacted by an overall shortage of water. However, the 
tendency of large landholders as well as small farmers is to irrigate as much land as possible, 
despite the inadequacy of the available water supply over the entire growing season. The LBOD 
system has yet to be optimized since it has lowered the water table by about 1 m in a restricted 
zone  of  a  1 km  radius  of  each  tubewell  installed  in  some  locations,  and  has  not  reduced  the 
salinity  of  the  soil  nor  restored  its  productivity.  The  eastern  part  of  Mirpurkhas  and  Sanghar 
districts lies outside the canal-irrigated system and hence the project area.  
 
8. 
Each side of the Indus floodplain is irrigated by canals emanating from the Kotri barrage. 
In  the  absence  of  an  adequate  drainage  system,  about  16.8%  of  the  farm  area  has  become 
waterlogged  and/or  salinized  while  the  area  under  forest  cover  has  shrunk  to  1.35%.  The 
irrigation  system  has  been  adversely  affected  by  an  overall  and  increasing  shortage  of  water; 
yet the tendency of all farmers is to irrigate more land than can be done by the limited supply 
from the canals.  
 
Human and Economic Development. The total population of the four districts is about 
9. 
4.2  million.  Income  is  generally  sourced  from  agriculture.  Villages  are  facing  shortages  of  all 
agricultural  inputs,  and  exhibit  severely  impoverished  and  degraded  environments.  Overall, 
64.8%  of  the  villages  have  a  population  of  less  than  50  households.  They  have  neither 
commercial nor small-scale enterprises that can add value to their produce. Even the urbanized 
communities  with  limited  agro-industry  bear  a  rural  character  and  exhibit  a  highly  degraded 
environment.  
 
 
10.  Wildlife  Populations.  Very  little  upland  wildlife  is  present  in  the  project  area  owing 
mainly to intensive habitat modification brought about by extensive cultivation and dense human 
population.  The  persistent  species  include  gray  francolins,  rabbits,  and  raptorial  birds.  A  small 
peacock population is still present, though in a protected status in a few locations. The recent 
expansion in sugarcane production in the canal command area has benefited the wild boar (Sus 
scrofa)  population,  which  utilizes  the  extensive  cane  fields  for  both  food  and  shelter,  and  has 
greatly multiplied in number. 
 
Several lakes and wetlands (e.g., Tando Bago, Phoosna, Charwo, and Khanjo lakes in 
11. 
Badin district and Jafri and Mahboob Shah lakes in the coastal area of Thatta district) are home 
to  significant  waterfowl  habitat.  The  natural  and  artificial  shallow  lakes  are  wintering  areas  for 
waterfowl  populations  that  breed  in  Siberia.  Large  flocks  of  ducks,  including  marbled  and 
whistling teals, pintail, mallard, gadwall, red-crested pochard, shoveller, and ruddy shelduck are 
present on these water bodies from about September to March. Other common species are little 
grebe,  grayleg  goose,  pelican,  and  black-winged  stilt.  Thatta  district  also  includes  the  Kinjhar,

D. 

Screening of Potential Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures  

The  appropriate  ADB  guidelines  were  selected  and  a  checklist  of  environmental 
12. 
parameters  was  used  to  identify  and  screen  the  potential  environmental  impacts  of  different 
project  components  and  to  suggest  possible  mitigation  measures.  In  the  absence  of  ADB 
guidelines  specific  to  multisector  small-scale  interventions  proposed  in  a  rural  development 
project such as the present one and in order to comply with ADB's environmental assessment 
requirements, the specific guidelines consulted for screening of proposed project interventions 
were  as  follows  (i) Selected  Infrastructure  Projects:  Highways  and  Roads;  and  (ii) Selected 
Infrastructure Projects: Water Supply. 
 

1. 

Upgraded Rural Infrastructure and Settlement Improvement 

13. 
Under this project component, it is proposed to upgrade two types of rural roads. First, 
around  750  km  of  gravel  village  link  roads  will  connect  selected  villages  either  directly  to  the 
district road network or to a neighboring village itself connected to the district network. Second, 
for  selected  clusters  of  project  villages  interconnected  by  village  link  roads,  the  Project  will 
provide  for  some  200  km  of  bituminous  district  link  roads  that  will  connect  the  cluster  to  the 
existing  district  road  network.  The  village  link  roads  will  have  a  raised  embankment  and  a 
compacted  carriageway  of  suitable  material  (gravel  or  broken  bricks)  and  associated  small-
scale structures (culverts and short-span bridges) to provide year-round access. The district link 
roads will generally be 3.1–3.6 m wide, with compacted gravel shoulders including side ditches, 
drainage  structures,  and  short  bridge  spans  as  required.  In  general,  district  link  roads  will 
typically  be  3–4  km  in  length,  and  village  link  roads  2–3  km,  and  both  will  follow  existing 
alignments,  but  with  flexible  geometric  design  standards  to  avoid  land  acquisition  and 
involuntary resettlement.  
 
14. 
The  types  of  road  envisaged  for  upgrading  are  of  a  small  scale  and  the  traffic  is 
expected to be limited and localized. All roads will be located in areas that have little remaining 
natural environment, and the selection process includes conducting an environmental sensitivity 
screening  and  compliance  with  strict  environmental  impact  criteria.  The  potential  impacts  are 
primarily  construction  related.  The  nature  of  the  work  will  be  entirely  rehabilitation  or 
improvement  of  existing  alignments,  and  the  construction  periods  are  expected  to  be  short. 
Appropriate design and construction standards that will be monitored and followed by timely and 
suitable  maintenance  will  ensure  effective  mitigation  of  potential  minor  environmental impacts. 
The  prevalent  problem  of  surface  ponding  during  the  rainy  season  will  be  addressed  by 
ensuring  adequate  cross  drainage.  The  Project  will  provide  training  to  the  communities 
responsible for the operation and maintenance of the village link roads.

During  construction  of  the  district  roads,  there  will  be  some  minor  and  temporary 
disruption to the surroundings and the environment. Potential environmental issues may include 
soil  erosion,  siltation  and  increase  in  runoff,  waste  generation  and  effluent  from  temporary

These  issues  will  be  minimized  through  appropriate  environmental  management  measures

(i) construction  area  should  be  restricted  to  minimize  area  disturbed;  (ii) soil  erosion  control 
methods  should  be  incorporated;  (iii) watering  of  construction  sites  to  reduce  dust  should  be 
undertaken;  (iv) waste  management  measures  should  be  introduced  at  construction  sites  and 
camps;  (v) hazardous  materials  should  be  safely  stored;  (vi) groundwater  contact  should  be 
minimized during construction; (vii) vegetation disruption should be limited at construction sites 
and  removal  of  significant  habitat  vegetation  avoided;  and  (viii) disturbed  areas  should  be 
returned to previous conditions or an improved state. All mitigation requirements will be included 
in the contract document for the contractor and for sensitive areas a performance bond system 
might  be  included.  Monitoring  of  environmental  effects  of  the  construction  activities  will  be 
undertaken  by  the  project  engineer.  At  the  operation  stage,  periodic  microbiological  testing  of 
groundwater  will  be  undertaken. In areas close to sensitive areas such as wetlands the water 
table  and  water  sources  will  be  carefully  monitored  in  terms  of  any  changes  in  hydrology  and 
water  quality.  Structured  and  planned  preventive  maintenance  programs  will  be  developed  for 
all facilities constructed under the Project and for existing facilities. 
 

2. 

Improved Rural Livelihoods 

17. 
The objective of this component is to strengthen the performance of tenants, agricultural 
laborers,  and  marginal  owners-cum-tenants  through  improvements  to  crop  cultivation  and  on-
farm water management practices, horticulture, and livestock. The proposed interventions were 
assessed in terms of their sustainability. The examination was conducted within the context of 
previous land use regimes, which have already brought about severe losses to land productively 
over  extensive  areas  through  the  twin  processes  of  waterlogging  and  salinity.  The  agriculture 
interventions  proposed  in  the  project  will  result  in  a  reduction  of  the  amounts  of  fertilizer  and 
pesticides  discharged  into  the  environment,  and  will  have  positive  environmental  impact. 
Similarly  improvement  in  farming  activities  will  reduce  the  degree  of  waterlogging  and  soil 
salinity  of  the  land.  This  component  will  not  require  any  further  environmental assessment or 
monitoring. 
 
E. 

Institutional Requirements and Environmental Monitoring 

18. 
Environmental impact considerations are included as one of the selection criteria for the 
rural  infrastructure  subcomponent.  Moreover,  for  each  rural  infrastructure  intervention,  an 
environmental sensitivity screening will be conducted. Consultants and the Sindh Environmental 
Protection Agency will ensure that environmental assessments, where required, are conducted 
and  adequately  endorsed,  and  that  standards  are  upheld.  Government  approved  laboratories 
will  be  used  to  test  the  drinking  water  and  provide  quality  monitoring  after  construction  of  the 
schemes.  Implementation  of  mitigation  measures  during  the  construction  stage  will  be  the 
responsibility of the contractor under the supervision of the relevant district government office.

F. 

Findings and Recommendations 

19. 
The  overriding  environmental  impact  on  the  project  area  has  been  the  extensive 
waterlogging  and  salinization  caused  by  the  Indus  Basin  irrigation  system.  As  a  result,  the 
project  area  has  extensive  tracts  of  land  that  is  no  longer  suitable  for  cultivation.  The  level  of 
intervention  and  expenditure  needed  to  correct  this  situation  is  clearly  beyond  the  capacity  of 
the  Project.  But  careful  attention  to  soil  fertility  and  groundwater  conditions  in  planning  and 
implementing particular agricultural and infrastructure interventions will be given in order to bring 
local  improvement  in  land  capability.  In  the  case  of  construction-related  impacts,  these  are 
localized  and  temporary  in  nature  and  can  be  minimized  through  careful  planning,  proper 
construction practices and efficient environmental monitoring. 

 
Overall, the Project is not expected to result in adverse environmental impacts. It is even 
20. 
likely  to  bring  about  positive  impacts,  including  (i) improved  management  of  fertilizer  and 
pesticide inputs, (ii) improved water management, and (iii) greater environmental awareness of 
the communities. 
 
G. 

Conclusions 

21. 
The  IEE  has  shown  that  no  major  impacts  will  arise  from  the  Project  that  warrant 
examination  by  a  full  environmental  impact  assessment.  This  is  also  in  accordance  with  the 
framework  of  Pakistan’s  National  Conservation  Strategy,  which  is  the  fundamental  national 
policy  document  on  environmental  protection  and  natural  resource  conservation.  Individual 
interventions  are  at  small  scale,  focusing  on  individual  villages  or  clusters  of  villages.  These 
interventions  are  not  expected  to  have  major  negative  environmental  impacts.  However,  if 
properly  implemented,  improvements  and  strengthening  of  land  use  performance,  including 
cultivation,  livestock  rearing  and  water  use  improvements,  have  the  potential  to  improve 
environmental conditions within the project area.
